answers.body_markdown:
When you set the Qt::Popup flag, the widget position must be absolute, that is to say with respect to the screen, but option.rect is a QRect relative to the viewport, so the solution is to convert that relative path to absolute using mapToGlobal but for that you must pass a parent to the editor

<pre><code>def createEditor(self, parent, option, index):
    editor = NspDateEdit(<b>parent</b>)
    editor.setWindowFlags(QtCore.Qt.Popup)
    return editor

# ...

def updateEditorGeometry(self, editor, option, index):
    <b>r = QtCore.QRect(option.rect)
    if editor.windowFlags() & QtCore.Qt.Popup and editor.parent() is not None:
        r.setTopLeft(editor.parent().mapToGlobal(r.topLeft()))
    editor.setGeometry(r)</b></code></pre>

View inheritance mode in Odoo can be done in two types of `mode`, `primary` and `extension`. Primary `mode` view inheritance creates a totally new view which can be used as a separate view while `extension` which is default value if not mentioned, will add inheritance to the existing view. Either change inheritance mode to `extension` or bind your `userscustom` view to a new action to keep the original functionality unchanged.

answers.body_markdown:
I think you may be slightly confused about `<br>` tags.  `<br>` or `<br />` are self-closing/void elements/empty tags:

https://www.w3schools.com/html/html_elements.asp (under the empty html section)
http://xahlee.info/js/html5_non-closing_tag.html

>`<br>` is an empty element without a closing tag (the `<br>` tag defines a line break):

So when you're subbing in `<br><br />` you're actually subbing in two line breaks.  From your description it sounds as if you only want one line break, so you'll want to remove one of them.

items.body_markdown:
I am running a LSTM network to classify a huge database of remote sensing sequences to their respective landcovers. Code is developed on Tensorflow/Keras and I am trying models with 3 to 7 layers, each having 16 to 64 LSTM cells. Due to huge data size (around 13.5M sample sequences), I am interested to do my model training in distributed mode by data parallelization over multiple GPUs or multiple PCs.  However, my tries by now have not resulted in any improvement over single system version and I am thinking if it is feasible at all or not.

My understanding from data parallelism under Tensorflow/Keras is that there are different workers, a chief, and a parameter server (ps). Model parameters are stored in ps and communicated with workers and chief, and each worker works on a partition of the whole data. Each worker should get the model parameters from ps at the start of each data batch processing, do all the forward and backward propagation and calculate the weight updates and send them back to ps, where the updated model parameters are calculated by chief and stored. Therefore, each worker should read the model parameters before each batch processing.

My simulation batch size is 1024, therefore there are about 13K batches in one epoch of data. Training of a model with 87,000 parameters took 412 seconds in my one-gpu system, which means about 30 ms per batch. A more complex model with 1M parameters took 1900 seconds to process one epoch, which means about 146 ms per batch.
Now that I look at the numbers, I am in doubt if data parallelism is helpful. If two GPUs or CPUs want to communicate 100K or 1M parameters, can it be so fast to be done in a few milliseconds to be negligible? My experiments on a two-GPU system (which even doesn't require data transmission over network) resulted in batch processing time of twice single-GPU. Can it be attributed to the small batch processing time compared to data communication overhead on top of that? If it is, does it mean that my model is not as complex as necessary for distributed learning?
items.title: Is distributed learning feasible for my application?

answers.body_markdown:
Surely, the connection is valid. When you pass null arguments to `psycopg2.connect()` like you have done then the program gets [Postgres environment variables](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/libpq-envars.html) which are apparently set up properly. Note that this is not true in the case you pass a DSN string to the function:

	conn = psycopg2.connect("host=None") # this defines an invalid connection

Per [the documentation](http://initd.org/psycopg/docs/module.html#psycopg2.connect):

> The PostgreSQL documentation contains the complete list of the [supported parameters](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/libpq-connect.html#LIBPQ-PARAMKEYWORDS). Also note that the same parameters can be passed to the client library using [environment variables](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/libpq-envars.html).

answers.body_markdown:
**`[2..-1]` doesn't work, because the *array of indices* created with `..`, the [range operator](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_operators#range-operator-), in this case is `2, 1, 0, -1`**, which is not what you intended.

Unfortunately, **as of PowerShell Core 7.0.0-preview.4, the only way to refer to _all remaining_ elements (or all remaining elements except the _last N_) is via an expression based on the array's _element count_, which requires you to capture the array in a _variable_ first**:

```
Get-ChildItem -File -Recurse -Path "$Env:USERPROFILE\Documents" |
    ForEach-Object {
        $components = $_.DirectoryName.Split('\')
        $components[2..($components.Count-1)] -join '\'
    }
```

**Future outlook:** Providing a convenient index syntax that allows referencing all remaining elements (with `[2..]`) as well as all remaining elements except the last `$n` (with something like `[2..@-$n]`), is the subject of [this feature request on GitHub](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/7940).

Note: A pipeline-based solution via `Select-Object -Skip 2`, as shown in [js2010's answer](https://stackoverflow.com/a/58071435/45375), is convenient, but noticeably _slower_ than an array-slicing solution.

---

As for **what you tried**:

**Providing a *fixed* upper bound such as `999` that is known to always be higher than the true element count works IF AND ONLY IF (a) that bound is known and (b) is low enough not to cause memory / performance problems.**

Therefore, using something like `2..([int]::MaxValue-1)` is _not_ an option.

(In practice, in PowerShell Core the highest index you can use is `[int]::MaxValue - 1048576` (`[int]::MaxValue - [Math]::Pow(2, 20))`) - but generating an array with that many elements (serving as indices) with `..` is prohibitively slow and memory-intensive).

---

**If performance is paramount**, use a solution based on `.Substring()` that simply omits the path prefix based on the input path:

```
$inputPath = "$Env:USERPROFILE\Documents"

# Determine the length of the prefix 
# comprising the input path's first 2 path components.
$prefixLength = ($inputPath -replace '^(.+?\\.+?\\).*', '$1').Length

Get-ChildItem -File -Recurse -Path $inputPath |
 ForEach-Object {
   $_.DirectoryName.Substring($prefixLength)
 }
```

Another way, skip the first 2.  

```
Get-ChildItem -File -Recurse -Path $Env:USERPROFILE\Documents |
  ForEach { ($_.DirectoryName.Split('\') | select -skip 2) -join '\' }
```

If you're trying to delete the first 2 folders in the fullname, here's another way.  The replace method doesn't use regex, but is case sensitive.

```
Get-ChildItem -File -Recurse -Path "$Env:USERPROFILE\Documents" | 
  foreach { $_.fullname.replace('C:\Users\','')}
```

answers.body_markdown:
Rather than write a function to filter the `dir()` results, use the attributes `__all__` and/or `__dir__` to let your module publicly export the namespace explicitly, as described in [PEP 0562](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0562/).

    # lib.py
    deprecated_names = ["old_function", ...]
    __all__ = ["new_function_one", "new_function_two", ...]
    
    def new_function_one(arg, other):
       ...

    def new_function_two(arg, other):
        ...
    
    def __dir__():
        return sorted(__all__ + deprecated_names)


Usage:
    
    # main.py
    import lib

    dir(lib)  # prints ["new_function_one", "new_function_two", "old_function", ...]

*Note:* The module level `__dir__` hook requires Python 3.7+.

---

**Edit:** Perhaps you will be interested in the [`who`](https://ipython.readthedocs.io/en/stable/interactive/magics.html#magic-who) and [`whos`](https://ipython.readthedocs.io/en/stable/interactive/magics.html#magic-whos) magic commands provided in an IPython interactive session. Demo shown below.

    >>> who
    Interactive namespace is empty.
    >>> x = 123
    >>> def foo():
    ...     pass
    ... 
    ... 
    >>> who
    foo	 x	 
    >>> whos
    Variable   Type        Data/Info
    --------------------------------
    foo        function    <function foo at 0x109b59158>
    x          int         123

answers.body_markdown:
Solution 1:
```
evensAndOdds : List a -> (List a, List a)
evensAndOdds items
  let
    enum = List.indexedMap Tuple.pair items
    evens = List.filterMap (\(i, v) -> if modBy 2 i == 0 then Just v else Nothing) enum
    odds = List.filterMap (\(i, v) -> if modBy 2 i == 1 then Just v else Nothing) enum
  in
    (evens, odds)
```

Solution 2:
```
evensAndOdds : List a -> (List a, List a)
evensAndOdds =
  List.indexedMap (\i v -> (modBy 2 i == 0, v))
  >> List.partition Tuple.first
  >> Tuple.mapFirst (List.map Tuple.second)
  >> Tuple.mapSecond (List.map Tuple.second)
```
answers.title: How to split a list into two lists by even and odd positions?

answers.body_markdown:
Single pass and much less code:

    evensAndOdds : List a -> (List a, List a)
    evensAndOdds =
      List.foldr (\item (a, b) -> (item :: b, a)) ([], [])

The trick here is to switch the position of the elements of the returned tuple on each iteration, thereby alternating which one is appended to without having to keep track of the index.
answers.title: How to split a list into two lists by even and odd positions?

answers.body_markdown:
You can also use a recursive function. It may be easier to read than `fold`, especially for beginners.

    evensAndOdds : List a -> ( List a, List a )
    evensAndOdds input =
        case input of
            [] ->
                ( [], [] )
    
            [ even ] ->
                ( [ even ], [] )
    
            [ even, odd ] :: tail ->
                let
                    ( tailEvens, tailOdds ) =
                        evensAndOdds tail
                in
                ( even :: tailEvens, odd :: tailOdds )

answers.body_markdown:
As noted by Lyndon, the problem was that you didn't write `Ref{T}` in the type signature. 

For fun, here's my implementation a promise type, though I'm sure there's a more elegant way that's makes more effort to pretend to be immutable. 
```julia
struct Promise{T} <: Ref{T} 
    r::Ref{T}
    fufilled::Ref{Bool}
end
Promise{T}() where {T} = Promise{T}(Ref{T}(), Ref(false))
Promise() where {T}    = Promise{Any}(Ref{T}(), Ref(false))

function Base.getindex(p::Promise) 
    @assert p.fufilled[] == true
    p.r[]
end

function deliver(p::Promise{T}, val::U) where {U <: T}
    p.r[] = val; p.fufilled[] = true
    p
end

isrealized(p) = p.fufilled[]
```

Now if we go the repl and, we can check how this acts:
```julia
julia> x = Promise(); # If we know we'll deliver an Int then we should do Promise{Int}()

julia> isrealized(x)
false

julia> deliver(x, 1);

julia> x[]
1
```
Delay should be quite similar.

answers.body_markdown:
If your objective is to avoid running out of memory JVM-wide, then the garbage collector is the right guy for the job. I suggest you use [soft-values][1], like so:

    Cache<String, Cache<String, List<String>>> cache = CacheBuilder.newBuilder()
            .softValues()
            .build();

This sets up a cache which wraps any value it stores in a [SoftReference][2]. Softly-referenced objects will be garbage-collected in a globally least-recently-used manner in response to memory demand and entry invalidated in the cache.


  [1]: https://guava.dev/releases/snapshot/api/docs/com/google/common/cache/CacheBuilder.html#softValues--
  [2]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/ref/SoftReference.html
answers.title: How to cache data via Guava Cache using available memory as parameter?

answers.body_markdown:
There is no good way for Guava's Cache -- or any on-heap cache implementation, honestly -- to do what you ask.  Soft references may appear to work, but are much more likely to cause awful behavior -- e.g. your JVM may perform continuous, constant full garbage collections.

The best way to address this issue is really and truly to experiment and find a `maximumSize` parameter that works for you.  Your implementation will not work, either, as it doesn't attempt to weigh one particular entry.

answers.title: Which commit was a specific release on rubygems created from?

answers.body_markdown:
Simple answer: You cannot!

Versions of a gem on Rubygems and commits or tags in Git are two totally different concepts and have nothing in common. 

You already discovered that the gem doesn't contain any information about the use of git or a specific commit. And if you think about that it makes sense that gems do not contain information about the version control system that was used:

 - There is no need to use Rubygems and Git at the same time. Actually, there is no need to use a version control system at all when you build gems.
 - And even if the author used a version control system, there are other version control systems – like SVN or Mercurial for example.
 - Even if the author used Git to keep track of their source code changes, they could still create and upload multiple different versions of the gem without doing a single git commit in the meantime.
 - And even if the author did a commit for every gem version then – depending on the configuration of the gem and the git repository – both systems can include files which exist on one system but not on the other.

That said, the assumption that a specific gem version corresponds with a specific git commit is just wrong.
answers.title: Which commit was a specific release on rubygems created from?

answers.body_markdown:
It seems you want Monday as the first day of week.  datefirst does that.
Since you have P1 listed multiple times, the data is not normalized and it is not easy to sort.  I have taken the data and added a sortorder row for sorting.  It's basically a sorted unique ID.

After that, calculate the first day of the week and then union it with each of the next 4 weeks.


    set datefirst 1
    
    declare @Input table (Product varchar(2), Product_Date date, Units int)
    
    insert into @Input
       values('P1','2019-09-01',10),
             ('P1','2019-09-04',20),
             ('P2','2019-09-27',30)
    
    declare @Input_Normalized table
       (Product varchar(2), Product_Date date, Units int, SortOrder int)
    
    insert into @Input_Normalized
    select *, row_number() over (order by Product, Product_Date, Units) SortOrder
    from @Input
    
    select *
    from (
       select Product, Product_Date,
          DATEADD(DAY, 1 - DATEPART(WEEKDAY, Product_Date), Product_Date) Week_Start,
          0 Units, SortOrder
       from @Input_Normalized
    ) a
    union all
    (
       select Product, Product_Date,
          DATEADD(DAY, 8 - DATEPART(WEEKDAY, Product_Date), Product_Date) Week_Start,
          Units, SortOrder
       from @Input_Normalized
    )
    union all
    (
       select Product, Product_Date,
          DATEADD(DAY, 15 - DATEPART(WEEKDAY, Product_Date), Product_Date) Week_Start,
          Units, SortOrder
       from @Input_Normalized
    )
    union all
    (
       select Product, Product_Date,
          DATEADD(DAY, 22 - DATEPART(WEEKDAY, Product_Date), Product_Date) Week_Start,
          Units, SortOrder
       from @Input_Normalized
    )
    union all
    (
       select Product, Product_Date,
          DATEADD(DAY, 29 - DATEPART(WEEKDAY, Product_Date), Product_Date) Week_Start,
          Units, SortOrder
       from @Input_Normalized
    )
    order by SortOrder, Product, Week_Start

Note this does not produce the same output that you have.  This is because 9/1/2019 is not in the week beginning on 9/2/2019.  This seems like an error in what you expect for output.  If 9/1/2019 should indeed be in the week beginning on 9/2/2019, you'll have to explain how/why.

items.body_markdown:
I work as a backend developer and we have **iOS** and **Android** frontends. Recently we had an idea that it would nice to build some kind of framework in the mobile app which would be capable of rendering typical form questions based on the JSON returned by the backend. JSON will contain a list of questions that should be asked during the journey. That is, we agree on the question types and backend will return strings/configurations which frontend will use to build questions of the specific types.

Basically, to have backend return following JSON:

    {
        "questions": [
            {
                "id": "54543543",
                "type": "COMBOBOX",
                "title": "Random title",
                "subtitle: "Random subtitle",
                "options": [
                    "Text 1",
                    "Text 2"
                ],
                "selected": 1
            }
            ...
        ]
    }

It will give us additional flexibility if we would like to:

- Restructure form flow (add/remove/rephrase/move questions of the existing types) - we won't need to force customers to update the app if we want to change anything in the form.
- A/B test to see how conversion rate improves or how responses from our integration partner change based on the answers provided by the customers (there are a lot of optional parameters that may influence the results).
- Reuse the same engine to build similar forms for entering other countries - less boilerplate, only purely presentational logic on the mobile app side.

However, there are also drawbacks of this approach:

- The solution is technically complex - even though it reduces boilerplate, it introduces technical complexity. Nothing like this was built in the company before and many people will be against that (the company, in general, prefers to keep complexity at bay and use only standard approaches/tools as opposed to building in-house solutions).
- It is not entirely flexible - still, the frontend will have to program specific question types (layouts) in the app. Some JSON responses for certain layouts will be very complex and nested to make sure that the frontend is able to build beautiful and functional questions.
- It will be much harder to onboard newcomers on both frontend and backend to maintain this part of the system.
- Fewer people will be willing to review the code - given the fact that frontend pull requests need at least 2 approvals - may take them longer to build/fix anything there.

What do you think? My main concern is customer experience - we won't need to ask customers to update the app. 50%-60% of our customers have auto-updates enabled. Also, flexibility to fix typos/adjust the forms may be very useful, especially if integration partners decide to change their API or if we would like ourselves change the journey and ask more/less information. However, it means that we will have to build our own framework which may get out of hand at some point, especially if the founders leave the company/team.
items.title: Dynamic form rendering framework in mobile app

answers.body_markdown:
Either you use a Remote Interface which leads to marshalling and unmarshalling (performance) or you introduce a module dependency from the WARs to the EAR by adding deployment.MY_DEPLOYMENT_NAME e.g. to `jboss-deployment-structure.xml`. Then you use the same classloader, but your WARs might go offline while you redeploy the EAR.

See e.g. https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/jboss_enterprise_application_platform/6.1/html/development_guide/chap-Class_Loading_and_Modules#Dynamic_Module_Naming1

for documentation.
answers.title: Using same classloader for ear and war

answers.body_markdown:
There can be different solutions.

1) Package into the EAR those WARs only that use EJBs. Then you can use EJBs via local interfaces. All other WARs can still be deployed independently, and they *don't need* the same class loader as EAR.
<br/>

2) Use remote EJBs. Package into WARs the interfaces of EJBs that they use. Again, no need in the same class loader. And if you are worried about performance of remote EJBs, then first test the real püerformance. Jboss developers have optimized performance a lot. For instance, [read here][1], they optimized EJB calls

> ... to avoid doing unnecessary server side communication(s) which
> would typically involve network calls, marshalling/unmarshalling etc.

<br/>
3) Analyze dependencies of WARs and EJBs, also dependencies between EJBs on each other. Try to identify 4-5 groups or "clusters" of EJBs and WARs that are very close to each other and that use only a few EJBs from other groups, or even use no EJBs from other groups. Then package such groups into separate EARs. For instance, you can have:

 - A main EAR that provides 20 EJBs responsible for user and permission management
 - One EAR with 10 EJBs and 5 WARs for product management
 - One EAR with 20 EJBs and 30 WARs for order management
 - One EAR with ... EJBs and ... WARs for shipment management

Then in the most cases you will deploy only one of these EARs and thus your deployment times will be 4-5 times faster.


  [1]: https://docs.jboss.org/author/display/AS71/Remote+EJB+invocations+via+JNDI+-+EJB+client+API+or+remote-naming+project?_sscc=t
answers.title: Using same classloader for ear and war

answers.title: Django: When a user uploads media to my site, it is owned by the server's root user. How do I change this?

answers.body_markdown:
> My server is running Django, and django_user is the owner of Django and it’s files. However, when a user uploads a file/photo using the form submission, it is placed under the ownership of my servers root user. 

If Django is really running as `django_user`, then it cannot create files owned by `root`, and it cannot change the ownership or permissions of files owned by root.

Therefore, we must assume that your "form submission" must be implemented by something other than Django.  Possibly it is the host webserver ... though that *shouldn't* be running as `root` either.

There are two ways you could address this:

  - You could change the code that is implementing the form (as `root`) to change the ownership of files after they are uploaded.  

  - You change your system's architecture so that the form us run as the `django_user` user.

------------

If the form is actually implemented in Django, then that is evidence that Django is not running as `django_user`.
answers.title: Django: When a user uploads media to my site, it is owned by the server's root user. How do I change this?

answers.body_markdown:
The coventional Pythonic idiom for your code is a bit off, you don't want to use 'is None', ([list of things Python returns as None][1]), and also, for nan testing you need to import math. I believe this is what you are looking for:
```
import math

if 'value1' in results_dict:
    if results_dict['value1']:  #is not None just means it exists, so eliminate that
        if not results_dict['value1']['limit']: #is None just means not
            temp = {'limit':math.nan} #create new dict
            results_dict['value1'].update(temp) #update your level 1 nested dict
            res.append(math.isnan(results_dict['value1']['limit'])) #correct nan test
        else:
            res.append(results_dict['value1']['limit'])
    else:
        res.append(math.isnan(results_dict['value1']['limit'])) #correct test for nan
else:
    res.append(math.nan) #correct assignment of nan
```
See also:
[Assigning a variable NAN in Python][2]

Edit: if you are not looking to assing NAN specifically, then your code can be greatly simplified.
```
if 'value1' in results_dict:
    if results_dict['value1']:
        if results_dict['value1']['limit']:
            res.append(results_dict['value1']['limit'])
    else:
        res.append('')
else:
    res.append('') #correct assignment of nan
```
Actually it's really not clear what the question is here... What is your res supposed to be a list of? Truth values? Dict values?

  [1]: https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html
  [2]: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/19374254/assigning-a-variable-nan-in-python-without-numpy/19374296

answers.body_markdown:
The second-line is not an import. What they're doing is declaring a new variable. They are destructuring the object returned from `Dimensions.get("window")`. In layman's terms we can say they're extracting some named-data from the output. Then they use the semi-colon to rename it to something else.

    const { width: totalWidth } = Dimensions.get("window");

The object returned might look like this:

    { width: 100, height: 200 }

So they took the key-value pair of **width**, and created a new variable:

    const width = 100

Then they renamed **width** to **totalWidth**:

    const totalWidth = 100

That sequence is all done in one short, nice-line.

answers.body_markdown:
In your code you're using HMAC hashing which takes the algorithm parameter `sha256` or `sha384`. These algorithm names are not identical to the algorithm names that can be used in a JWT.

In [RFC 7517 section 4.1.1](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7515#section-4.1.1)
you can read about the `alg` header:

>A list of defined "alg" values for this use can be found in the IANA
   "JSON Web Signature and Encryption Algorithms" registry established
   by [JWA]; the initial contents of this registry are the values
   defined in Section 3.1 of [JWA].

According to [RFC7518 section 3.1](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7518#section-3.1) for HMAC ShaXXX algorithms, you have you use `HSXXX`, e.g `HS256` or `HS384`

The [JWT.io](https://jwt.io) debugger or any other software that tries to verify the JWT reads this header and then tries with the algortihm. If you use a non standard name, the verifying software can't find the right algortihm.


A note regarding the use of [JWT.io](https://jwt.io): don't forget to paste the secret into the input field under `Verify Signature` in the right column of the debugger, **before** you paste the token into the left column. If you forget the secret, the token can't be verifyed and if you paste the secret after the token, the signature might get recalculated and changed on the left side.

Regarding the updated request, I had a similar problem, with binding together columns of different lengths.
I solved by writing a wrap of `cbind` that also add `NA` values.

    cbind.NA <- function (...) {
       myDFs <- list(...)
       myDFs <- lapply(myDFs, as.matrix)
       n <- max(sapply(myDFs, nrow)) 
       do.call(cbind, lapply(myDFs, function(x) rbind(x, matrix(,n-nrow(x), ncol(x)))))
    }

Because you have `rows` and a list, you need to use `rbind` and convert the element of your list to `data.frame` before binding them together.

    newDF <- data.frame()
    for(i in 1:length(myList)){
       tmp <- as.data.frame(myList[[i]])
       names(tmp) <- names(myList[i])
       newDF <- cbind.NA(newDF,tmp) 
    }

    newDF
          a b  c
    [1,]  1 4  9
    [2,]  2 5 10
    [3,]  3 6 NA
    [4,] NA 7 NA

    t(newDF)
       [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]
    a    1    2    3   NA
    b    4    5    6    7
    c    9   10   NA   NA

answers.body_markdown:
This is the simplest solution I can conjure up using base R.



    
    cbindlist = function(list_obj){
      
      lengths = unlist(lapply(list_obj, length))
      NA_lengths = sapply(lengths, function(x) max(lengths) - x)
      cols = names(list_obj)
      
      out = data.frame(sapply(1:length(list_obj), function(x) c(list_obj[[x]], rep(NA, NA_lengths[x]))))
      colnames(out) = cols
      
      return(out)
    }

It works for both of your examples:
    
    lista = list(a = c(1, 2, 3), b = c(4, 5, 6, 7), c = c(9,10))
    newlista = list(a = c(1, 2, 3, "f"), b = c(4, 5, 6), c= c(9,10), d=list(1,2))

    > cbindlist(lista)
       a b  c
    1  1 4  9
    2  2 5 10
    3  3 6 NA
    4 NA 7 NA

    > cbindlist(newlista)
      a  b  c  d
    1 1  4  9  1
    2 2  5 10  2
    3 3  6 NA NA
    4 f NA NA NA

answers.body_markdown:
Much of this has been covered in other Q&As, but I'll give a summary here.  (And look for links to add).  Still, good question, it's useful to collect this all in one place.

----

**On x86, every asm load is an acquire-load**.  To implement that efficiently, modern x86 HW speculatively loads earlier than allowed and then checks that speculation.  (Potentially resulting in a memory-order mis-speculation pipeline nuke.)  To track this, Intel calls the combination of load and store buffers the "Memory Order Buffer".

Weakly-ordered ISAs don't have to speculate, they can just load in any order.

---

**x86 store ordering** is maintained by only letting stores commit from the store buffer to L1d in program order.

On Intel CPUs at least, a store-buffer entry is *allocated* for a store when it issues (from the front-end into the ROB + RS).  All uops need to have a ROB entry allocated for them, but some uops also need to have other resources allocated, like load or store buffer entries, RAT entries for registers they read/write, and so on.

**So I think the store buffer itself *is* ordered**.  When a store-address or store-data uop executes, it merely writes an address or data into its already-allocated store-buffer entry.  Since commit (freeing SB entries) and allocate are both in program order, I assume it's physically a circular buffer with a head and tail, like the ROB.  (And unlike the RS).

---

**Avoiding LoadStore is basically free**: a load can't retire until it's executed (taken data from the cache).  A store can't commit until *after* it retires.  In-order retirement automatically means that all previous loads are done before a store is "graduated" and ready for commit.

A weakly-ordered uarch that can in practice do load-store reordering might scoreboard loads: let them retire once they're not to be non-faulting but before the data arrives.

This seems more likely on an in-order core, but IDK.  So you could have a load that's retired but the register destination will still stall if anything tries to read it before the data actually arrives.  We know that in-order cores do in practice work this way, not requiring loads to *complete* before later instructions can execute.  (That's why software-pipelining using lots of registers is so valuable on such cores, e.g. to implement a memcpy.  Reading a load result right away on an in-order core destroys memory parallelism.)

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/52215031/how-is-load-store-reordering-possible-with-in-order-commit goes into this more deeply, for in-order vs. out-of-order.

---

### Barrier instructions

The only barrier instruction that does anything for regular stores is `mfence` which in practice stalls memory ops (or the whole pipeline) until the store buffer is drained.  https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50494658/are-loads-and-stores-the-only-instructions-that-gets-reordered covers the Skylake-with-updated-microcode behaviour of acting like `lfence` as well.

`lfence` mostly exists for the microarchitectural effect of blocking later instructions from even issuing until all previous instructions have left the out-of-order back-end (retired).  The use-cases for `lfence` fo memory ordering are nearly non-existent.

related:

* https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50323347/how-many-memory-barriers-instructions-does-an-x86-cpu-have
* https://stackoverflow.com/questions/56705436/how-can-i-experience-lfence-or-sfence-can-not-pass-earlier-read-write
* https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40409297/does-lock-xchg-have-the-same-behavior-as-mfence
* https://stackoverflow.com/questions/32705169/does-the-intel-memory-model-make-sfence-and-lfence-redundant
* https://stackoverflow.com/questions/51986046/understanding-the-impact-of-lfence-on-a-loop-with-two-long-dependency-chains-fo goes into a lot of detail about how LFENCE stops execution of later instructions, and what that means for performance.
* https://stackoverflow.com/questions/4537753/when-should-i-use-mm-sfence-mm-lfence-and-mm-mfence/50780314#50780314 high-level languages have weaker memory models than x86, so you sometimes only need a barrier that compiles to no asm instructions.  Using `_mm_sfence()` when you haven't used any NT stores just makes your code slower for no reason than `atomic_thread_fence(mo_release)`.
answers.title: how are barriers/fences and acquire, release semantics implemented microarchitecturally?

items.body_markdown:
A lot of questions SO and articles/books such as https://mirrors.edge.kernel.org/pub/linux/kernel/people/paulmck/perfbook/perfbook.2018.12.08a.pdf, Preshing's articles such as https://preshing.com/20120710/memory-barriers-are-like-source-control-operations/ and his entire series of articles, talk about memory ordering abstractly, in terms of the ordering and visibility guarantees provided by different barriers types. My question is how are these barriers and memory ordering semantics implemented on x86 and ARM micro architecturally ?

For store-store barriers, it seems like on the x86, the store buffer maintains program order of stores and commits them to L1D(and hence making them globally visible in the same order). If the store buffer is not ordered, ie does not maintain them in program order, how is a store store barrier implemented ? it is just "marking" the store buffer in such a way that that stores before barrier commit to the cache coherent domain before stores after ? or does the memory barrier actually flush the store buffer and stall all instructions until the flushing is complete ? Could it be implemented both ways ?

For load-load barriers, how is load-load reordering prevented ? It is hard to believe that x86 will execute all loads in order! I assume loads can execute out of order but commit/retire in order. If so, if a cpu executes 2 loads to 2 different locations ,how does one load ensure that it got a value from say T100 and the next one got it on or after T100 ? What if the first load misses in the cache and is waiting for data and the second load hits and gets its value. When load 1 gets its value how does it ensure that the value it got is not from a newer store that load 2's value ? if the loads can execute out of order, how are violations to memory ordering detected ?

Similarly how are load-store barriers(implicit in all loads for x86) implemented and how are store-load barriers(such as mfence) implemented ? ie what do the dmb ld/st and just dmb instructions do micro-architecturally on ARM, and what does every load and every store, and the mfence instruction do micro-architecturally on x86 to ensure memory ordering ?
items.title: how are barriers/fences and acquire, release semantics implemented microarchitecturally?

items.body_markdown:
Long story short: In Django web application on Apache2 (linux) and MySql (ISAM) we need safely reuse some records marked as `deleted`, instead of creating new ones. Even if more users may request such action at the same time, each of them should obtain different record for reusing.


----------


The background:

 - We have web application, where many users can do things at the same time.
 - there are tables, that grows to infinity, but only few records are active (sometimes like from 100.000 long records is active 1.000 and no chance for reactivating any "deleted")
 - sometimes are tranferred (to other places) just changes, so we mark "deleted" records as such and transfer them to delete records on the other side
 - sometimes is needed to transfer the tables (to partial place) as whole and it takes too long
 - the data integrity during the transfer is managed by other part of the project and should not do real problems 

Wanted:

 - reuse some old and long time "deleted" records for new data
 - it is not problem, to have `reuse_me` field in tables (default False, set to True after long time deleted, by some script). It can be safely assumed, that such records are nowhere referenced and do not reference nothing else (the script can delete all refereces from the record and mark only not refereced records, so tree-like structures would be freed in more steps - there are no cyclic structures to free anyway and if they will became, there can be other way to disable them as whole)
 - **there is problem, how to pick them to use, when more than one user may try it at the same time** (as side effect of being on web)

Simple solution (does not work for many cases):

 - some records are easy to write fully at one time by pure SQL (something like `UPDATE car_owners_cross SET deleted=0, resuse_me=0, owner_id=123, car_type_id=456 WHERE deleted=1 AND resuse_me=1 LIMIT 1;` ) and it would (should) select "random free record" and rewrite it, so it is no longer free and there should be no conflict. (also this would be done only if count of free records is higher than say 100, otherwise it would just be INSERTed - so no worrying about not finding free record in concurent access)

Total solution:

 - some records are more complicated and needs to be repeatedly updated, until task is done (like attach file, create related records, rewrite it depending on later web input ....) so there is need to know, **which record** was selected for the task for reuse - **and I do not know, how to do that**
 - the solution should be Django function returning `id` of reused/created object (or the object with valid id) - like `coc=reuse_or_create(models.Car_Owners_Cross, owner_id=123, car_type_id=456)` or `coc=models.Car_Owners_Cross.reuse_or_create(owner_id=123, car_type_id=456)` - while it would probably need some SQL/cursors/etc magic inside
 - I think, the solution would be easy, if there would be a way to get ID of the modified record - so it would take form of  `UPDATE car_owners_cross SET deleted=0, resuse_me=0 WHERE deleted=1 AND resuse_me=1 LIMIT 1;` get **id of that record** and then issue `UPDATE car_owners_cross SET  owner_id=123, car_type_id=456 WHERE id=789` - but **I do not know, how to get id of that record** 


----------
Notes:

 - there are plans for new feature, which would make the problem much worse (generating and deleting tons of records regularry, many times for no good use - while user just "plays with settings") while leaving just few non-`deleted` records after - so it would be big help, to have such feature there from start
 - in example above - each Owner can have any number of types of car (and any number of identical car types - so many records would have the same values, except for unique id) as well as any CarType can be owned by any number of Owners
 - the real records are way more complicated, but the principe is the same
 - the number of (`deleted`) records is already doing problems
 - the target is to improve ratio of `valid` to `deleted` records, not necessery to eliminate each and every "deleted" record (so it can keep a pool of `reuse_me` marked records to be sure, that `UPDATE` will get its victim and make new records, even if some `reuse_me` do still exist - the size of the pool can be configured in code, just need be "sane" - say like 3x number of expected concurently logged-in users or something like that
 - there is possibility to add other fields to affected tables, to support `reuse_me`, or make `reuse_me` any other type, than boolean
 - not all creation of new record will use this possibility (eg. Admin interface would still just plainly use `INSERT` (`coc=Car_Owners_Cross();...;coc.save();`) and some old tools too)
 - if this function will be used, all defaults can be "manually" set by code to valid values (would be nice to have them on default values (just to be extra safe - but not exactly requested)
 - not all tables will be used this way (and only tables from our own models will be, so no auth.* etc.)
items.title: How safely reuse database records in MySql from Django (in Apache)

answers.body_markdown:
The MF RC522 is a reader IC, not a writer IC from NXP:
https://cdn-shop.adafruit.com/datasheets/rfid+guide.pdf

There are some libraries for Arduino that you can use and write (only ISO 14443 A, not B) with an RC522 module - but they are limited and not every RFID-module is able to use it.

So, if you want a good library for the RC522, check this:
https://github.com/miguelbalboa/rfid

And this is the code:

    mfrc522.MIFARE_Write(blockNumber, bytes, bytesLen);

Where the block number is a number from 0 to 15, bytes your array and byteslen the length of your array.

You can find a complete tutorial here: https://lastminuteengineers.com/how-rfid-works-rc522-arduino-tutorial/

To write a link in this TAG, you can put a link as text (not the good way) or you can write the TAG as "well known type", using an identifier type (like "https://" or "http://" as code). To this, you have to format your NFC with the NDEF format. Check this tutorial for more info:
https://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-pn532-rfid-nfc/ndef

As said, the RC522 is really limited and you will probably fail to write a right formatted NDEF message on you NFC chip.

If you have the possibility, try to upgrade your module to a PN532 IC. This is also really old, but the most used in the Arduino world.

The following is not the most performance query, but I think it does what you want:

    select top (1) with ties sn.*
    from security_name sn
    where sn.securityid in (select opv.securityid from option_price_view opv) and
          sn.ticker <> 'ZZZZ'  -- gets rid of NULL values too
    order by row_number() over (partition by sn.securityid order by date desc);
answers.title: Select specific record using case as if

answers.body_markdown:
Well, I think you want to include the rows where ticker is null or 'ZZZZ' if they are the ONLY row.  If so, I have come up with the following.

This is **UNTESTED** and may have syntax errors.

Comments are inline.

    select * -- You will probably want to enumerate the relevant columns because this will also return the rown number column
    from ( -- I use 2 paremeters for order by so that ticker is null and ticker = 'zzzz' are the lowest priority
       select SN.*, row_number() over ( partition by securityid
                                  order by case when isnull(ticker,'ZZZZ') = 'ZZZZ' then 1 else 0 end,
                                  date desc ) rownum
       from security_name SN
       inner join ( -- I like to inner join but this could be in the where clause "where in" or "where exists"
          select distinct securityid
          from option_price_view
       ) OPV on OPV.securityid = SN.securityid
    ) SN_a -- This completes the subquery returning everything ordered by our desired priority
    where rownum = 1 -- This limits the output to the single highest priority record for each securityid
answers.title: Select specific record using case as if

I am basically looking to pull security_name data for all security ids present in the option_price_view.

Security_name has multiple records for a single securityid, the latest for some having the ticker "ZZZZ" or null. I want to condition it so that if there is only one record, grab it, whatever it may be. If there are multiple, pull the one with the latest date and a ticker is not null or <> "ZZZZ"

the security_name table has the following fields:
Securityid, ticker, date, issuerdescription

I have tried multiple nested selects to try to filter out "ZZZZ" or null values but I do not understand the syntax for IF number of records = 1, select it, else select the next record ordered by date desc.

    select * from security_name 
    where securityid in 
    (
    	select distinct securityid 
    	from option_price_view
    )
    and ticker <> "ZZZZ"
    and ticker is not null

What happens here is that any records in security_name that do not have multiple records, will not populate.

I have a binary classification problem, and have been asked to write functions for  Largest, Smallest and medium rectangle classifiers. Also I have to write functions for circle and ellipsoid classifiers. I am a beginner and know how to use various classifiers in python, but I have no idea what largest/smallest , circle classifiers are. I have been given code for smallest rectangle classifier in which condition has been set for one classifier. 

    #Implement a function that returns min/max price/engine power values that define a rectangle classifier

    def getRange_familyCar(gdf):
      min_price = gdf[gdf['c']==1]['p'].min()
      max_price = gdf[gdf['c']==1]['p'].max()
      min_engine = gdf[gdf['c']==1]['e'].min()
      max_engine = gdf[gdf['c']==1]['e'].max()
    
      return min_price, max_price, min_engine, max_engine

There are 3 columns, with 'p' and 'e' columns as dependent variables and 'c' target class column.

items.body_markdown:
I’m trying to create object pool in C# but I can’t find proper data structure for this task. List<T> looked promising with removing data from the end but unfortunately it misses much needed feature namely combination of GetRange() and RemoveRange(). Using both methods one after another is undesirable as it’s creates new List<T> and copies result thus allocating garbage. It’s especially annoying while dealing with mutable structs. I’m well aware that using mutable structs is not recommend, but for some reason Unity Team decided to implement Vector3 as struct. 

Also, I was thinking on using ArraySegment<T> but that approach seems messy. Stack<T> too was a promising collection but unfortunately does not contain PopRange(), PushRange(). 

Do anyone knows about third-part List<T> or other collection that contains such behavior?
items.title: Why List<T> does not have ExtractRange()?

answers.body_markdown:
try this

    grep -Pc '(\wowner)|(owner\w)' file

the word should have either a prefix or suffix (so the standalone won't match).  Note that this will count the number of lines that have a match.  To count the occurances

    grep -oP '(\wowner)|(owner\w)' file | wc -l
answers.title: Counting number of words that contain a substring with grep
